column5: 100 seatsWith a handful of races still to be decided

column9: versus the Democrats' 44 seats and two independents. The Democrats' leader in the next Senate is expected to be New York's Chuck Schumer.The Republicans this year were defending 24 seats. The Democrats defended 10 seats and gained only one
column13: retained their majority in the House of Representatives and lost fewer seats than anticipated. Members of the House serve two-year terms and all are up for re-election every two years.To advance most bills in the House
column14: 218 votes or more are needed. Republicans went into the elections holding 246 seats to the Democrats' 186. There were three vacancies.The Republican leader is Speaker Paul Ryan of Wisconsin; the Democrats' leader is Nancy Pelosi of California. To win a majority

column1: 8	8	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-spending-idUSKBN1341JR	At under $5 each
column2: Trump's votes came cheap	"

column1: By Ginger Gibson and Grant Smith
| WASHINGTON

WASHINGTON Donald Trump pulled off one of the biggest upsets in American political history when he toppled Hillary Clinton in the U.S. presidential election on Tuesday - and he did it using far less cash than his rival.    Relying heavily on an unorthodox mix of social media
column2: unfiltered rhetoric
column3: and a knack for winning free TV time
column4: the New York real estate businessman likely paid less than $5 per vote during his insurgent White House bid
column6: according to a Reuters analysis of campaign finance records and voting data. Those figures assume the candidates spent all the funds they raised.    Trump's cost-effective win has upended prevailing concepts about the influence of money in American politics and raised the question of whether a lean
column7: media-savvy campaign can become the new model for winning office in the United States.    Political strategists and academics tend to agree
column9: that Trump's performance would be tough to repeat. A household name for his luxury brand resorts
column11: and ability to surround himself with non-stop controversy
column12: Trump held advantages that many political candidates lack.    ""I think this is a case where Trump had unique characteristics as a candidate that allowed him to pursue a different type of strategy
column14: a professor of government at Colby College in Maine.     In total
column15: Trump raised at least $270 million since launching his campaign in June 2015
column16: a little more than a third of the money that Obama's re-election campaign spent in 2012
column17: according to the most recent filings with the Federal Elections Commission. With vote counting wrapping up in the early hours of Wednesday
column18: Trump had won some 59 million votes nationwide in the general election. That amounts to less than $5 per vote for the $270 million he spent.

column1: According to data analytics firm mediaQuant
column2: Trump garnered about $5 billion worth of free media coverage during the election campaign
column3: more than twice the amount earned by Clinton
column4: a lifelong politician who served as secretary of state
column6: and first lady at different times in her career.    mediaQuant adds up all the unpaid coverage the candidates earn in newspapers
column7: magazines and social media and then compares the sum to what a comparable amount of coverage
column8: with the same kind of reach
column9: would have cost in advertising.     Trump has also frequently dominated news cycles with provocative rhetoric that breaks taboos
column10: including unabashed insults targeting women he dislikes over Twitter
column11: or unusual policy proscriptions like his call to temporarily ban Muslims from entering the country to prevent domestic attacks
column12: or to force Mexico to pay for a multi-billion dollar border wall to keep out immigrants.

column1: BIG DONORS

column4: replicating the small dollar fundraising juggernaut of another insurgent candidate

She spent more than $237 million on television ads and more than $42 million on hundreds of staffers.    She also benefited from spending by the Super PACs supporting her candidacy
